H: description
Groundwater generally is low in N/P but can have high concentrations of base cations such as calcium and magnesium.
pH of groundwater depends on bedrock and pH of precipitation. On limestone, pH can be as high as 8.5
Due to weather variability, habitats that depend on precipitation as the main watersource are also occasionally succeptible to dry periods
Water from precipitation generally has very low buffering capacity and thus is prone to acidifying processes
Precipitation is low in phosphate and usually nitrogen (note that nitrogen deposition can be substantial in polluted areas).
As surface flow generally depends on accumulated waterflow over a larger watershed scale, nutrient concentrations can be significant.
Surface fed habitats can occasionaly become flooded or severely waterlogged.
Where surface flow depends on precipitation, periods of low rainfall can induce conditions of drought.
Local (micro-) topography determines depth to water table.
Local (micro-) topography determines depth to water table.
High nutrient availability tends to increase maximum height (Ordoñez et al. 2010), although this relationship is not always sginificant (Douma et al. 2012)
Emergent species grow tall to stay above the water level; some species exhibit plastic shoot elongation in response to flooding
The proportion of clonal growth species is large in wetlands; particularly rhizomatous growth in permanently wet habitats and reproduction by fragmentation where surface water flow occurs
Root depth decreases with increasing permanent wetness
Stem specific density decreases with permanent wetness
Stem specific density tends to increase with decreasing nutrient availability
Increased root depth can be a response to nutrient limitation, increasing forage soil volume
Low nutrient availability tends to decrease maximum height (Ordoñez et al. 2010), although this relationship is not always sginificant (Douma et al. 2012)
Species adapted to dry conditions tend to have higher stem specific density
Increased nutrient availability decreases number of individuals per area
